title: God’s Judgment and Promise
shortSummary: Isaiah 65 contrasts the rebellious behavior of Israel with God's gracious calling of a faithful remnant and the promise of a new creation. The chapter reveals God's judgment on unrepentant sinners and His blessings on His servants, culminating in a vision of peace and restoration in the new heavens and new earth.
timeline: c. 8th century BC - Isaiah's prophetic ministry during the late 8th century BC, addressing Judah before the Babylonian exile

keyCharacters.name: The LORD
keyCharacters.description: God who speaks directly in this chapter, declaring judgment on the rebellious and promising blessings to His faithful servants.

keyCharacters.name: The rebellious people
keyCharacters.description: Those who reject God’s call, engage in idolatry and sinful practices, provoking God’s anger and judgment.

keyCharacters.name: God’s servants
keyCharacters.description: The faithful remnant who seek the LORD, receive His blessings, and inherit the new creation.

keyCharacters.name: Jacob and Judah
keyCharacters.description: Represent the nation of Israel and the tribe of Judah, from whom God will bring forth a faithful seed to inherit His promises.

definitions.definition: Idolatrous worship practices involving offerings made in private gardens rather than the temple, indicating syncretism and rebellion against true worship.
A valley near Jericho historically associated with trouble and judgment, here symbolically transformed into a place of blessing and rest.
A prophetic vision of God’s ultimate renewal of creation where former troubles are forgotten and eternal peace is established.
An expression of God’s intense displeasure and anger toward the sinful actions of the people.

outline.heading: God’s Invitation and Israel’s Rebellion
outline.description: God reveals that He has been seeking those who did not seek Him, but Israel has persistently rebelled through idolatry and hypocrisy, provoking His anger.

outline.heading: Judgment on the Wicked and Mercy for the Faithful
outline.description: God declares He will repay the iniquities of the rebellious while preserving a faithful remnant, highlighting the consequences of rejecting His call.

outline.heading: Blessings for God’s Servants
outline.description: A contrast is drawn between the fate of the wicked and the blessings promised to God’s servants, including a new identity and relationship with the God of truth.

outline.heading: The New Creation and Eternal Joy
outline.description: God promises a new heavens and earth where sorrow and death are no more, and peace and prosperity reign, culminating in a vision of harmony among all creatures.

application: Respond to God’s invitation by seeking Him earnestly, even if you have not done so before.
Repent from rebellious and idolatrous behaviors that provoke God’s anger and choose to live in obedience to His will.
Trust in God’s promise of restoration and eternal joy, looking forward to the new heavens and new earth He will create.
Live as God’s servant by rejoicing in Him, knowing He hears and answers prayer promptly.

keyVerses.text: I am sought of them that asked not for me; I am found of them that sought me not: I said, Behold me, behold me, unto a nation that was not called by my name.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights God’s sovereign grace in seeking out those who did not seek Him, emphasizing His initiative in salvation.

keyVerses.text: For, behold, I create new heavens and a new earth: and the former shall not be remembered, nor come into mind.
keyVerses.significance: A powerful promise of God’s ultimate renewal and restoration, offering hope beyond present suffering and judgment.

keyVerses.text: And it shall come to pass, that before they call, I will answer; and while they are yet speaking, I will hear.
keyVerses.significance: This verse assures believers of God’s attentive and immediate response to their prayers, encouraging confident faith.

keyVerses.text: The wolf and the lamb shall feed together, and the lion shall eat straw like the bullock: and dust shall be the serpent's meat. They shall not hurt nor destroy in all my holy mountain, saith the LORD.
keyVerses.significance: A vivid depiction of peace and harmony in God’s eternal kingdom, symbolizing the complete restoration of creation.
